moves.1. e4 c5: This is an appropriate response. I did it in about 2 of my games.
moves.2. Nf3: Nc3 might have focused on the center even better, but this still helps in future positions.
moves.2... Nc6: A normal response puting pressure on d4.
moves.3. b3: Fiancetto? was that my plan. Or bishop A3?
moves.3... Nf6: Nc3 would help fiencettoing, and put all four knights out in a nice way. His fine position helped mine.
moves.4... d6: These past moves are what I call a "double development." The pawns are out there. Plus it gets ready to launch other minor pieces.
moves.5. Bb5: This is, "a ruy lopez two moves later."
moves.5... Bd7: Many of you probably do that. The only problem is it must stay there pinned for position.
moves.6. Bb2: I have my favorite pieces left on the first rank.
moves.6... e6: D5 has pressure for a fight I would not win.
moves.7. Bxc6: This may have not been wise, but my bishop would stay there anyways.
moves.7... Bxc6 8. d3: I needed one more piece in able to make e4 safe. This just completely changes the look of the board too. Closed to open in one move.
moves.8... Be7 9. Qe2: Left open for any direction of castling
moves.9... e5: I was pushing on e5, so he needed to block it.
moves.10. O-O-O O-O: And with that, we both castled and made a change again.
moves.11. h3: I don't have a clue what I was thinking there. Maybe I didn't think I had good options so I wasted a move.
moves.11... b5 12. Rhe1: I needed to break my rooks through to do some damage.
moves.12... b4: My knight was in trouble. I couldn't believe that I responded Nb1! It WAS a good option though.
moves.13. Nb1 Qa5: I played Soumya Kalkarni, (920) the game before. She tried to break in the sides too. That game ended I lost. It is a good plan.
moves.14. a4: I was risking en passant, but it was the only way to stop  a pawn and position loss.
moves.14... Rfe8: Someone who watches this game, please explain this move to me.
moves.15. Nbd2: I was trying to advance, not retreat.
moves.16. g3: Now I remember; my plan was to advance the free pawns.
moves.16... d5: Now we started the major exchange on d5.
moves.17. exd5 Rxd5 18. Nc4: That change sure opened the position.
moves.18... Qa6: Next I charged at the free E5 pawn, 4 of my players on it.
moves.20... Rxd6 21. Qd2: A rook in the pin defended three ways puts more pressure on him. I control the E file now!
moves.21... Rdd8: His rook is no longer safe there
moves.22. Bxf6 gxf6 23. Rxe8+ Rxe8: Now that we exchanged, we get down to the endgame pretty fast. But it lasts a long time.
moves.24. Re1 Rxe1+ 25. Nxe1: It was currently in a draw position, but i thought I could still win.
moves.26... Kg7: My queen could now not come in. It took me a while to advance.
moves.27. Qf4 Qa6: I was wondering, "what is he doing there?"
moves.28. Qc4: Going for a pawn or a queen trade, less wanted, or likely.
moves.28... Qa5: I knew it. He couldn't go for it.
moves.29. Qg4+ Kf8 30. Qc8+ Be8: Now I had him pinned! Later I get his bishop.
moves.33. Ka2 Qd4 34. Qa8: I just gave him a free pawn. But by this point there were only 9 minute on my clock.
moves.34... Qc3 35. Qxa7 Qxc2+ 36. Ka1 Qxf2 37: Oh no! I was losing all my pawns; A weakness I have in the endgame.
Distracting him with a promotion run.
moves.41... Bb5 42. Qf3 Bxd3 43. Qg3+ Kf8: I was going to call 3 move repetition. After I forced it. But it didn't work out. Kh6 was there to go.
moves.46. Qe1 Qxb3 47. Nf4 Bf5 48. Qg1+ Kf8 49: And here I when it happened: A free bishop!
moves.49... Ke8 50. Qxf5 Qa3+ 51. Kb1 Qc3: Oh no! He will soon promote a pawn.
QG3 is what what I did, Qg2 affect if I could capture or not. Qg2 got accidentally played. So note: I cannot capture. I would if I could.
moves.57. a7 Qd3+ 58. Kb2 Qd4+ 59. Kxb3 Qxa7:
From this possition, I stopped notating. I had only 3:12 secconds left. I am amazed if you look at the USCF rating change. It ended up a draw. I was 2 1/2 out of 5 games for the tournament. My rating went up 142 at the end of the tournament. Goodbye for now, 

Joshua. P
